participants: georgia chestnuts rust-ing on an open fire

messages.sender: georgia chestnuts rust-ing on an open fire
messages.message:
Hi team! Do we have any recommendations for how to save a copy (for back up) of entire workspace in case the drive crashes or the project folder is corrupted/extreme worst case inceident takes place? BofA has a project with more than 50k documents that they need to back up and the folder is too large to download/copy.

Any advice for this would be much appreciated!
cc: @shaunak

messages.sender: georgia chestnuts rust-ing on an open fire
messages.message: If the answer is to break up the folder enough to be able to download, I will accept that as well!
@Heymian
haha yes try to break the folder up into smaller chunks and download those.

messages.sender: georgia chestnuts rust-ing on an open fire
messages.message: Ooof, sounds good. Do we know what size we can no longer download folders? @Heymian
you might still run into limits, so there’ll be some trial-and-error unfortunately. :disappointed:
it’s a function of both the number of files and the size, because we have to download everything and then attempt to zip up 50k files. It’s a lot of memory but also just a lot of files.

messages.sender: georgia chestnuts rust-ing on an open fire
messages.message: Are there any stats I can reference to make it somewhat easier for them? Or just trial and error?

messages.sender: georgia chestnuts rust-ing on an open fire
messages.message: trial and error

messages.sender: georgia chestnuts rust-ing on an open fire
messages.message: Would like to avoid BofA being like this :point_up:

I don’t off the top of my head. i think their lives will probably suck, i don’t think we can even do 1000 files, total size < 1GB,. :disappointed: Our zipping code is pre-dates me and hasn’t been worked on since.
do they have direct access to the file system. they could just run a command line call to download it that way
@achao do you remember any ballmark numbers from issues in the past?
I think it would be easier to download directly from S3/NFS
since everything on instabase will live there also

messages.sender: georgia chestnuts rust-ing on an open fire
messages.message: And then do what? Upload it to a different storage system for back up? Or bitbucket?

messages.sender: georgia chestnuts rust-ing on an open fire
messages.message: COE team can download from S3
Ya upload it to wherever they planned to originally

iirc I think our load balancer cuts http sessions off at 30 minutes? cc @Ashish (ref https://console.cloud.google.com/net-services/loadbalancing/details/http/k8s-um-instabase-prod-ingress-server-nginx--a9f442dbfe56c755?project=instabase-main&authuser=1&folder&organizationId&supportedpurview=project&tab=details&duration=PT1H)

messages.sender: georgia chestnuts rust-ing on an open fire
messages.message: They didn't plan for somewhere to upload it - they are looking for our recommendation for backing up solutions.
i think downloaded it, zipping it locally and uploading as a compressed file to another drive would be the safest
If they have access to the s3 console / command line then they could easily directly copy to another s3 bucket
@achao in production the load balancer timeout should be set to 5 minutes
Nevermind. It looks like it is 30 minutes.

Is they are using s3 to store the data, they could also consider enabling s3 versioning. Then they don’t have to download/upload  anything and amazon will keep a history of older snapshots of the data in the bucket.
my understanding is they use HCP which isn’t hosted by amazon. If HCP supports versioning, would be good to enable for sure
